sections.text:
Fig. 10. Hot test setup at UC Davis.
Fig. 11. Performance of the 220-GHz TWTA with output power and gain plotted for the two operating conditions: high gain (solid points) and wide-bandwidth (hollow points).
Fig. 12. RF Power output at four distinct frequencies.
corresponds to a voltage of 20.9 kV, whereas the high-power operation mode corresponds to 21.8 kV. In wide-bandwidth operation: a gain of 24 dB was achieved over a bandwidth of 14 GHz starting at 207 GHz. In high-power operation: a gain of over 30 dB was achieved with a bandwidth in excess of 5 GHz starting at 197 GHz. As seen from the cold test results, the circuit’s bandwidth was almost 50 GHz, however, the hot test experiment was limited by available drive power at higher frequencies and hence the full performance of the TWTA was not evaluated.
To evaluate the maximum power achievable with the sheet beam TWTA, a CPI VKY2441T1 extended interaction oscillator operating in G-band was employed to obtain the saturation output power curve (see Fig. 12). The saturation drive power was about 300 mW demonstrating over 110 W of output power with over 25 dB of gain.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text:
A 220-GHz ultrawideband sheet beam TWTA has been developed under the DARPA HiFIVE program. Hot test measurements were conducted for wide-bandwidth and highgain performance of the tube. A wideband MMIC-based RF driver was employed with an output power of about 45 mW. At 20.9-kV gun voltage, output power of 11 W corresponding to a moderate gain of 27 dB has been measured at 214 GHz with a 3-dB bandwidth of 14 GHz from 207 to 221 GHz. The power-bandwidth product (defined as the product of peak power and 3-dB bandwidth) in this case is 154 W-GHz. For high-gain operation of tube at a gun voltage of 21.8 kV, output power of 107 W corresponding to 33-dB gain was measured at 201 GHz with a 3-dB bandwidth of 6 GHz from 197 to 203 GHz. This gives a power-bandwidth product of 642 W-GHz. An extended interaction klystron (EIK) was utilized for saturated gain measurements demonstrating over 110 W of power at 212.5 GHz.
The viability of nano-CNC milling of the sheet beam double staggered vane grating (DSG) array in OFHC copper has also been demonstrated, with submicrometer level machining tolerances and nanoscale surface roughness. The diffusion bonding of the three layers of the TWTA circuit to accommodate the overhead tapered vane input and output couplers has been conducted successfully. The S-parameter measurements clearly showed a TWTA passband exceeding 50 GHz with an insertion loss of about 5 dB. Sheet beam analyzer results experimentally demonstrated 438-A/cm2 circuit current density with 12.5:1 aspect ratio produced by a nanocomposite scandate tungsten cathode. The HiFIVE TWTA demonstration has laid the foundation for a PCM-QM-based lightweight approach to a subterahertz RF source [72], [73]. UC Davis has already taken a step toward this compact source concept by integrating fabrication offsets in 3-D full model simulations for realistic device output performance and setting tolerances for machining and assembly based on experimental beam measurement results. Hence, for the development and hot test demonstration of this 325-W-GHz TWTA, significant progress has been made to advance the enabling technologies for the realization of microscale, adequately powered, near-terahertz wideband amplifiers.
ACKNOWLEDGMENT
The authors would like to thank L. Barnett and Y.-M. Shin for their valuable contributions in the early stages of the program. Ji Li of BVERI graciously provided the cathode used in the sheet beam gun, and Alex Spear was instrumental in the data acquisition for the sheet beam gun analyzer. J. Pasour and J. Hanna of NRL kindly loaned and helped operate the EIK used in the large signal saturation studies.

metadata.abstractText: corresponds to a voltage of 20.9 kV, whereas the high-power operation mode corresponds to 21.8 kV. In wide-bandwidth operation: a gain of 24 dB was achieved over a bandwidth of 14 GHz starting at 207 GHz. In high-power operation: a gain of over 30 dB was achieved with a bandwidth in excess of 5 GHz starting at 197 GHz. As seen from the cold test results, the circuit’s bandwidth was almost 50 GHz, however, the hot test experiment was limited by available drive power at higher frequencies and hence the full performance of the TWTA was not evaluated. B. Saturated Power Operation
